title: Accessibility Statement - Find a Court or Tribunal - GOV.UK
h1: Accessibility statement for the ‘Find a Court or Tribunal’ service
p1: This accessibility statement applies to content published on www.find-court-tribunal.service.gov.uk
p2: This website is run by HM Courts and Tribunals. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website, so we have designed it to be accessible. For example, that means you should be able to:
bullets: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
navigate most of the website using just a keyboard
navigate most of the website using speech recognition software
listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
p3: We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.
p4: AbilityNet has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.
p21: The website has been tested by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC) and meets the required level of accessibility for compliance with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines v 2.1.
p6: If you need information on this website in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read or audio recording or braille:
p7: We’ll consider your request and get back to you within 10 working days.
h4: Reporting accessibility problems with this website
p8: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of this website. If you find any problems  not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, contact
p9: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint, contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS) (opens in a new window).
h6: Contacting us by phone or visiting us in person
p22: Contact information for all courts and tribunals can be found through the Find a court or tribunal service.
p11: We provide a text relay service for people who are D/deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
p12: Our courts and tribunals have audio induction loops, or if you contact us before your visit we can arrange a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter.
h7: Technical information about this website’s accessibility
p13: HM Courts and Tribunal Service is committed to making its websites accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.
p14: This website is fully compliant with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.1 AA standard.
p15: This statement was prepared on 3 December 2020. It was last reviewed on 24 June 2022.
p16: This website was tested at all stages of its build and subjected to Pa11y testing throughout May 2022 and a full Digital Accessibility Centre(DAC) assessment on 14 June 2022.
p17: This is an excerpt from the DAC report explaining their methodology:
p18: “The service is tested by a team of experienced auditors and analysts, many of who are disabled individuals and users of adaptive technology. The combination of subjective pan-disability user feedback and comprehensive technical auditing allows us to measure how the service performs technically and practically, thereby offering an essential added dimension to our test results that other methods of testing cannot provide.”
p19: “Manual accessibility checking was conducted by a team of disabled individuals, using a range of adaptive technologies (hardware and software designed to facilitate the use of computers by people with disabilities).”
p20: “Technical auditing involves the experienced application of a number of technical auditing and standards compliance assessment tools. This combined with an extensive knowledge of WCAG, its application and wider global practice provides the DAC website with further credibility and quality.”
